Detailed Description

Interface to global information about an application environment.

This is an abstract class whose implementation is provided by the Gaia system. It allows access to application-specific resources and classes, as well as up-calls for application-level operations such as launching activities, broadcasting and receiving intents, etc. 

 class RunningTasksPage : public gaia::core::Page {
     // Self-defined constants
     gaia::core::Context* mCT;
     gaia::core::PageManager* mPM;

 public:
     virtual void onInit(gaia::core::Persistence* const p);
 };

 void RunningTasksPage::onInit(gaia::core::Persistence* const p) {
     mCT = new Context(this);
     mPM = new PageManager(mCT);

     RunningTaskInfoArray array = mPM->getRunningTasks(NUM_RUNNING_TASKS);
     size_t numTasks = array.size() < NUM_RUNNING_TASKS ?
             array.size() : NUM_RUNNING_TASKS;
 }

Definition at line 73 of file Context.h.

Member Enumeration Documentation

anonymous enum

Flag for use with createPackageContext: include the application code with the context.

Enumerator:
CONTEXT_INCLUDE_CODE 
CONTEXT_IGNORE_SECURITY 

Flag for use with createPackageContext: ignore any security restrictions on the Context being requested, allowing it to always be loaded.

CONTEXT_RESTRICTED 

Flag for use with createPackageContext: a restricted context may disable specific features.

For instance, a View associated with a restricted context would ignore particular XML attributes.

Definition at line 795 of file Context.h.

enum gaia::core::Context::DelegateOption

The Delegate operation flag option.

Enumerator:
BIND_ABOVE_CLIENT 

Flag for bindDelegate(Demand* demand, DelegateConnection* conn, int32_t flags): indicates that the client application binding to this delegate considers the delegate to be more important than the app itself.

When set, the platform will try to have the out of memory kill the app before it kills the delegate it is bound to, though this is not guaranteed to be the case.

BIND_ADJUST_WITH_PAGE 

Flag for bindDelegate(Demand*, DelegateConnection*, int32_t): If binding from an page, allow the target degelate's process importance to be raised based on whether the page is visible to the user, regardless whether another flag is used to reduce the amount that the client process's overall importance is used to impact it.

BIND_ALLOW_OOM_MANAGEMENT 

Flag for bindDelegate(Demand*, DelegateConnection*, int32_t): allow the process hosting the bound degelate to go through its normal memory management.

It will be treated more like a running degelate, allowing the system to (temporarily) expunge the process if low on memory or for some other whim it may have, and being more aggressive about making it a candidate to be killed (and restarted) if running for a long time.

BIND_AUTO_CREATE 

Flag for bindDelegate(Demand*, DelegateConnection*, int32_t): automatically create the degelate as long as the binding exists.

Note that while this will create the degelate, its onStartCommand(Intent, int, int) method will still only be called due to an explicit call to startDelegate(Demand). Even without that, though, this still provides you with access to the degelate object while the degelate is created.

Note that prior to ICE_CREAM_SANDWICH, not supplying this flag would also impact how important the system consider's the target degelate's process to be. When set, the only way for it to be raised was by binding from a degelate in which case it will only be important when that page is in the foreground. Now to achieve this behavior you must explicitly supply the new flag BIND_ADJUST_WITH_PAGE. For compatibility, old applications that don't specify BIND_AUTO_CREATE will automatically have the flags BIND_WAIVE_PRIORITY and BIND_ADJUST_WITH_PAGE set for them in order to achieve the same result.

BIND_DEBUG_UNBIND 

Flag for bindDelegate(Demand*, DelegateConnection*, int32_t): include debugging help for mismatched calls to unbind.

When this flag is set, the callstack of the following unbindDelegate(DelegateConnection*) call is retained, to be printed if a later incorrect unbind call is made. Note that doing this requires retaining information about the binding that was made for the lifetime of the app, resulting in a leak -- this should only be used for debugging.

BIND_IMPORTANT 

Flag for bindDelegate(Demand*, DelegateConnection*, int32_t): this degelate is very important to the client, so should be brought to the foreground process level when the client is.

Normally a process can only be raised to the visibility level by a client, even if that client is in the foreground.

BIND_NOT_FOREGROUND 

Flag for bindDelegate(Demand*, DelegateConnection*, int32_t): don't allow this binding to raise the target degelate's process to the foreground scheduling priority.

It will still be raised to at least the same memory priority as the client (so that its process will not be killable in any situation where the client is not killable), but for CPU scheduling purposes it may be left in the background. This only has an impact in the situation where the binding client is a foreground process and the target degelate is in a background process.

BIND_WAIVE_PRIORITY 

Flag for bindDelegate(Demand*, DelegateConnection*, int32_t): don't impact the scheduling or memory management priority of the target degelate's hosting process.

Allows the degelate's process to be managed on the background LRU list just like a regular application process in the background.

enum gaia::core::Context::FileMode

The file modes.

Enumerator:
MODE_PRIVATE 

File creation mode: the default mode, where the created file can only be accessed by the calling application (or all applications sharing the same user ID).

See also:
MODE_WORLD_READABLE
MODE_WORLD_WRITEABLE
MODE_WORLD_READABLE 

File creation mode: allow all other applications to have read access to the created file.

See also:
MODE_PRIVATE
MODE_WORLD_WRITEABLE
MODE_WORLD_WRITEABLE 

File creation mode: allow all other applications to have write access to the created file.

See also:
MODE_PRIVATE
MODE_WORLD_READABLE
MODE_APPEND 

File creation mode: for use with.

See also:
openFileOutput, if the file already exists then write data to the end of the existing file instead of erasing it.

Member Function Documentation

bool gaia::core::Context::bindDelegate ( Demand *  demand,
DelegateConnection *  conn,
int32_t  flags 
)

Connect to an application delegate, creating it if needed.

This defines a dependency between your application and the delegate. The given conn will receive the delegate object when its created and be told if it dies and restarts. The delegate will be considered required by the system only for as long as the calling context exists. For example, if this Context is an Page that is stopped, the delegate will not be required to continue running until the page is resumed.

Note: this method can not be called from an Subscriber component. A pattern you can use to communicate from an Subscriber to a Service is to call startDelegate with the arguments containing the command to be sent, with the service calling its Delegate#stopSelf(int) method when done executing that command.

Parameters:
demandIdentifies the delegate to connect to. The Demand may specify either an explicit component name, or a logical description (action, category, etc) to match an DemandFilter published by a delegate.
connReceives information as the service is started and stopped.
flagsOperation options for the binding. May be 0, BIND_AUTO_CREATE, BIND_DEBUG_UNBIND, BIND_NOT_FOREGROUND, BIND_ABOVE_CLIENT, BIND_ALLOW_OOM_MANAGEMENT, or BIND_WAIVE_PRIORITY.
Returns:
If you have successfully bound to the delegate, true is returned; false is returned if the connection is not made so you will not receive the delegate object.

By the way, for cild usage, you can type cidl to see more information. For example, in sdk/example/core/DelegateTest. You can use below command. cidl -I./ ITestRemoteDelegate.cidl

Context* gaia::core::Context::createPackageContextN ( const base::String &  packageName,
int  flags 
)

Return a new Context object for the given application name.

This Context is the same as what the named application gets when it is launched, containing the same resources and class loader. Each call to this method returns a new instance of a Context object; Context objects are not shared, however they share common state (Resources, ClassLoader, etc) so the Context instance itself is fairly lightweight.

Parameters:
packageNameName of the application's package.
flagsOption flags.
Returns:
A Context for the application.

Context* gaia::core::Context::getApplicationContextN ( )

Return the context of the single, global Application object of the current process.

This generally should only be used if you need a Context whose lifecycle is separate from the current context, that is tied to the lifetime of the process rather than the current component.

Consider for example how this interacts with registerReceiver(BroadcastReceiver, IntentFilter):

  • If used from an Page context, the receiver is being registered within that page. This means that you are expected to unregister before the page is done being destroyed; in fact if you do not do so, the framework will clean up your leaked registration as it removes the page and log an error. Thus, if you use the Page context to register a receiver that is static (global to the process, not associated with an Page instance) then that registration will be removed on you at whatever point the page you used is destroyed.

  • If used from the Context returned here, the receiver is being registered with the global state associated with your application. Thus it will never be unregistered for you. This is necessary if the receiver is associated with static data, not a particular component. However using the ApplicationContext elsewhere can easily lead to serious leaks if you forget to unregister, unbind, etc.

content::ApplicationPreferences* gaia::core::Context::getApplicationPreferencesN ( int32_t  permission)

Return a ApplicationPreferences instance for your application's package.

storage::File* gaia::core::Context::getCacheDirN ( )

Returns the absolute path to the application specific cache directory on the filesystem.

These files will be ones that get deleted first when the device runs low on storage. There is no guarantee when these files will be deleted.

Note: you should not rely on the system deleting these files for you; you should always have a reasonable maximum, such as 1 MB, for the amount of space you consume with cache files, and prune those files when exceeding that space.

Returns:
Returns the path of the directory holding application cache files.
See also:
#openFileOutput
#getFilePath
#getDir

Return a ContentResolver instance for your application's package.

storage::File* gaia::core::Context::getDirN ( const base::String &  name,
FileMode  mode 
)

Retrieve, creating if needed, a new directory in which the application can place its own custom data files.

You can use the returned File object to create and access files in this directory. Note that files created through a File object will only be accessible by your own application; you can only set the mode of the entire directory, not of individual files.

Parameters:
nameThe name of the file to get; can not contain path separators.
modeOperating mode. Use 0 or
See also:
MODE_PRIVATE for the default operation,
MODE_APPEND to append to an existing file,
MODE_WORLD_READABLE and
MODE_WORLD_WRITEABLE to control permissions.
Returns:
Returns a File object for the requested directory.
See also:
#openFileOutput
storage::File* gaia::core::Context::getExternalCacheDirN ( )

Returns the absolute path to the directory on the external filesystem ( that is somewhere on.

See also:
FileDirectory::getExternalStorageRootDirectory() FileDirectory.getExternalStorageRootDirectory()) where the application can place cache files it owns.

This is like

See also:
getCacheDir() in that these files will be deleted when the application is uninstalled, however there are some important differences:
  • The platform does not monitor the space available in external storage , and thus will not automatically delete these files. Note that you should be managing the maximum space you will use for these anyway, just like with
    See also:
    getCacheDir().
  • External files are not always available: they will disappear if the user mounts the external storage on a computer or removes it. See the APIs on
    See also:
    FileDirectory for information in the storage state.
  • There is no security enforced with these files. All applications can read and write files placed here.
Returns:
Returns the path of the directory holding application cache files on external storage. Returns null if external storage is not currently mounted so it could not ensure the path exists; you will need to call this method again when it is available.
See also:
#getCacheDir
storage::File* gaia::core::Context::getExternalFilesDirN ( const base::String &  type)

Returns the absolute path to the directory on the external filesystem ( that is somewhere on.

See also:
FileDirectory::getExternalStorageRootDirectory() FileDirectory.getExternalStorageRootDirectory()) where the application can place persistent files it owns. These files are private to the applications, and not typically visible to the user as media.

This is like

See also:
getFilesDir() in that these files will be deleted when the application is uninstalled, however there are some important differences:
  • External files are not always available: they will disappear if the user mounts the external storage on a computer or removes it. See the APIs on
    See also:
    FileDirectory for information in the storage state.
  • There is no security enforced with these files. All applications can read and write files placed here.
Parameters:
typeThe type of the file.
Returns:
Returns the path of the directory holding application files on external storage. Returns null if external storage is not currently mounted so it could not ensure the path exists; you will need to call this method again when it is available.
See also:
#getFilesDir

base::String gaia::core::Context::getPackageCodePath ( )

Return the full path to this context's primary Android package.

The Android package is a ZIP file which contains application's primary code and assets.

Note: this is not generally useful for applications, since they should not be directly accessing the file system.

Returns:
String Path to the code and assets.

void gaia::core::Context::invokeDelegate ( Demand *  demand)

Launch a new delegate.

You will not receive any information about when the delegate exits.

Note that if this method is being called from outside of an Delegate Context. This is because, without being started from an existing Page, there is no existing task in which to place the new page and thus it needs to be placed in its own separate task.

Parameters:
demandThe description of the page to start.

Demand* gaia::core::Context::queryStickyBroadcastN ( const DemandFilter &  filter)

Return the sticky Demand that matches the filter.

void gaia::core::Context::registerSubscriber ( const Subscriber &  subscriber,
const DemandFilter &  filter 
)

Register a Subscriber to be run when any broadcast Demand matches filter.

Parameters:
subscriberThe Subscriber to handle the broadcast.
filterSelects the Dntent broadcasts to be received.
bool gaia::core::Context::revokeDelegate ( Demand *  demand)

Stop a delegate.

Note that if this method is being called from outside of an Delegate Context. This is because, without being started from an existing Page, there is no existing task in which to place the new page and thus it needs to be placed in its own separate task.

Parameters:
demandThe description of the page to stop.
void gaia::core::Context::sendBroadcast ( const Demand &  demand)

Broadcast the given demand to all interested subscribers.

This call is asynchronous; it returns immediately, and you will continue executing while the subscribers are run. No results are propagated from subscribers and subscribers can not abort the broadcast.

Parameters:
demandThe Demand to broadcast; all subscribers matching this Demand will receive the broadcast.
void gaia::core::Context::startPage ( Demand *  demand)

Launch a new page.

You will not receive any information about when the page exits.

Note that if this method is being called from outside of an Page Context. This is because, without being started from an existing Page, there is no existing task in which to place the new page and thus it needs to be placed in its own separate task.

Parameters:
demandThe description of the page to start.
See also:
PackageManager::resolvePage
void gaia::core::Context::unbindDelegate ( DelegateConnection *  conn)

Disconnect from an application delegate.

You will no longer receive calls as the delegate is restarted, and the delegate is now allowed to stop at any time.

Parameters:
connThe connection interface previously supplied to bindDelegate().
void gaia::core::Context::unregisterSubscriber ( const Subscriber &  subscriber)

Unregister a previously registered Subscriber.

All filters that have been registered for this Subscriber will be removed.

Parameters:
subscriberThe Subscriber to unregister.
